abstractText: Abstract Taking the Hydrogen atom as an example it is shown that if the symmetry of a three-dimensional system is O(2)⊕Z2, the variables (r, ρ, φ) allow a separation of the variable φ, and the eigenfunctions define a new family of orthogonal polynomials in two variables, (r, ρ2). These polynomials are related to the finite-dimensional representations of the algebra gl(2) ⋉ R ∈ g(2) (discovered by S Lie around 1880 which went almost unnoticed), which occurs as the hidden algebra of the G2 rational integrable system of 3 bodies on the line with 2and 3-body interactions (the Wolfes model). Namely, those polynomials occur intrinsically in the study of the Zeeman effect on Hydrogen atom. It is shown that in the variables (r, ρ, φ) in the quasi-exactly-solvable generalized Coulomb problem new polynomial eigenfunctions in (r, ρ2)-variables are found.

Taking the Hydrogen atom as an example it is shown that if the symmetry of a three-dimensional system is O(2)⊕Z2, the variables (r, ρ, ϕ) allow a separation of the variable ϕ, and the eigenfunctions define a new family of orthogonal polynomials in two variables, (r, ρ2). These polynomials are related to the finite-dimensional representations of the algebra gl(2) ⋉ R3 ∈ g(2) (discovered
by S Lie around 1880 which went almost unnoticed), which occurs as the hidden algebra of the
G2 rational integrable system of 3 bodies on the line with 2- and 3-body interactions (the Wolfes model). Namely, those polynomials occur intrinsically in the study of the Zeeman effect on Hy-
drogen atom. It is shown that in the variables (r, ρ, ϕ) in the quasi-exactly-solvable generalized Coulomb problem new polynomial eigenfunctions in (r, ρ2)-variables are found.

The Hydrogen atom is one of the most fundamental systems in quantum physics and in Nature. Of course, it is present in practically all textbooks on quantum mechanics, see e.g. [1]. Usually, exploring O(3) geometrical symmetry, it is studied in spherical coordinates (r, θ, ϕ), see Fig.1, although parabolic coordinates (r + z, r − z, ϕ) are also used in different applications. The states are characterized by the well-known Coulomb quantum numbers (nr, ℓ,m) and the Laguerre polynomials Lnr(r) naturally occur in the eigenfunctions. In this Letter the coordinates (r , ρ , ϕ) are used for which the eigenfunctions are characterized by new orthogonal polynomials in two variables (r, ρ2).
Let us take the two body Coulomb system or, equivalently, the Hydrogen-like system (Ze,−e) in three-dimensional space. After center-of-mass separation we arrive at the threedimensional space of relative motion which will be parametrized by variables (r , ρ , ϕ), see Fig.1 for geometrical setting, here r = √ x2 + y2 + z2 is radius, ρ2 = x2 + y2, tanϕ = y/x, when expressed in the Cartesian coordinates of the space of relative motion.
The Hamiltonian in the relative space is of the form
H = 1 2µ p̂2 − α r , (1)
here α = Ze2 > 0 for the case of attractive charges, p̂ = −i~∇ is the momentum operator and we assume for simplicity a unit reduced mass, µ = 1 from now on and setting ~ = 1.
Instead of solving the Schrödinger equation
HΨ = EΨ ,
we introduce the operator
r (H − E) = ( −r 2 ∆− Er ) − α ≡ (H − α) , (2)
and look for its zero modes, here ∆ is the Laplacian. This is equivalent to the study of the spectrum of the operator H ,
H Ψ = αΨ , (3)
where α - the Coulomb parameter - plays a role the spectral parameter, while the energy E - the original spectral parameter - is considered fixed. This procedure resembles the introduction of the known Sturm representation in quantum mechanics.
Recently, in studying the Hydrogen atom in a constant uniform magnetic field it was shown a convenience of use the coordinates (r, ρ, ϕ) for the parametrization of the SO(2)⊕ Z2(z → −z)-sub-symmetry of the system (1), see [2]. Such coordinates imply a partial separation of variables - the variable ϕ can be separated out - and a representation of the wavefunctions of the Hydrogen atom as follows,
Ψ = ρ|m| e−βr zp eimϕ P (r, ρ;m, p) ≡ ΓP (r, ρ;m, p) , (4)
where m is the magnetic quantum number, z2 = r2 − ρ2, p = 0, 1 defines parity, and β = √ −2E. Here, the first two factors emerge from the asymptotic behaviour of the solutions at small and large distances, respectively, whilst the factor eimϕ is the eigenfunction of the z-component of the angular momentum Lz = −i∂ϕ, which is conserved. Eventually, the problem of finding the eigenfunctions Ψ is reduced to finding the eigenfunctions P (r, ρ).
Let us take
Γ = ρ|m| e−β r zp eimϕ , (5)
as the gauge factor and introduce the gauge rotated operator
h ≡ Γ−1H Γ . (6)

In general, the polynomials Pn are orthogonal with measure Γ 2, see (5). It seems evident that these polynomials form a complete basis, although the rigorous proof is absent. Those polynomials are not in the list of known orthogonal polynomials in two variables, see [3] and for a review [4]. For a given n > 0, the degeneracy/multiplicity is equal to n for even n = 2k, while for odd n = 2k+1 it is equal to 2k = n− 1: it is the number of points on the hypotenuse of the Newton triangle shown in Fig.3.

The phenomenon of the existence of the eigenfunctions of the smaller number of variables than ones, which appear in the Hamiltonian, was systematically observed for many-body problems where the potential depends on relative distances alone [10]. Such a situation is typical for the case of separation of variables. But it is not at all typical when the variables are not separated. This phenomenon was called in [10] beyond the separation of variables.

This Hamiltonian is already known in literature as the quasi-exactly-solvable extension of the Coulomb problem of the second kind under the name generalized Coulomb problem [11], see for review [12], Case VIII, in the radial form when the (generalized) centrifugal barrier is explicitly included. The case (25) corresponds to the absence of the centrifugal term and the kinetic energy given by the standard three-dimensional Laplacian. The Hamiltonian (25) depends on the parameter α, which for fixed integer n and parameter β (hence, the energy, E = −β2/2), is the eigenvalue in the spectral problem (24). In general, the eigenvalues in the spectral problem (24) are different. Different α’s define different Hamiltonians.

where the first D eigenpolynomials are polynomials in (r, u) variables with the same energy E = −β2 2 . Hence, we have D different Hamiltonians where in each of them we know one eigenstate explicitly in the form (27). It implies that new polynomial two-variable eigenfunctions P (r, u) of the Hamiltonian (25) are found(!) in addition to already known one-variable ones P (r).
As a conclusion we have to emphasize that in the case of potentials V (r, ρ), which are
invariant with respect to O(2)⊕ Z2, the representation (4) can be generalized to
Ψ = ρ|m| e−Φ(r,ρ) zp eimϕ F (r, ρ;m, p) . (28)
where Φ, F are function to find. This representation was successfully applied to the twobody neutral Coulomb system in a constant uniform magnetic field γ for the case of two lowest energy states of positive/negative parity: (n = 0, m = 0, p = 0/1) [2], where F = 1. By using the representation (28) the perturbation theory was easily developed,
Φ(r, ρ) = βr + γ2Φ1(r, ρ) + . . .+ γ 2kΦk(r, ρ) + . . . , F (r, ρ) = 1 ,
algebraically (for weak magnetic fields) up to a very high order and then few-parametric compact trial functions were built leading to highly accurate results for both energies and quadrupole moment for arbitrary magnetic fields. In the case of excited states with n > 0 the prefactor F (r, ρ) carries the information about the nodal lines in (r, ρ)-space. This prefactor can be found in the perturbation theory
F (r, ρ) = Pn(r, u;m, p) + γ 2P (1)(r, ρ) + . . .+ γ2kP (k)(r, ρ) + . . . ,
while both corrections Φk(r, ρ) and P (k)(r, ρ) are polynomials, their coefficients can be calculated by algebraic means. Usually, a polynomial correction P (k)(r, ρ) can be written as a finite linear superposition of the polynomials Pn(r, u;m, p). It will be done elsewhere.
If in (28) the exponential is chosen as Φ(r, ρ) = βr + Ar2/2 the quasi-exactly-solvable problem - the generalized Coulomb problem occurs with pre-factors in the form of the triangular polynomials {Qn(r, u)}i=1,...D ∈ Pn. In this case each Qn is a linear superposition of the eigenpolynomials P0,1,2,...n of the original Coulomb problem.
